The Library Director is appointed by the Township of Middletown.
"I am honored to return to my first library post as Provisional Library Director. Working alongside the staff, the Library Trustees and our resident support base, I look forward to helping the Library community address and overcome new challenges," said Kim Rinaldi.
Kim Rinaldi is currently the Full Time Area Manager for the Monmouth County Library, a position she has held since 2006. Since 2009, she has also worked for Marist College as Adjunct Instructor in Library Science. Previously, she was the Assistant Branch Manager for the Middletown Township Library 2005-06, then Branch Manager for the Altantic Highlands Library 2006-2007. Kim first worked as Library Page for the Middletown Township Library in 1989, branching into circulation, reshelving, computer work, reference, new book reviews, and more.

the WHO, released its third ever report summarizing carcinogenic risks to humans, and included processed meats for the first time.
Processed meats—foods like bacon, ham, sausages, canned meat and some cured meat products—were classified by IARC as “Group 1 Carcinogenic to Humans.” This means that there is strong causal evidence linking them to cancer. Human biomarkers of cancer and exposure data across continents proved this level of risk.
In addition to processed meats, some cooked meats are also proven to be carcinogenic. Red meat products (beef, lamb, pork and veal) were put into “Group 3,” which means IARC lacks evidence linking their ingestion to cancer.
“The IARC classifications bring the global scientific evidence on cancer-causing risks from foods together for worldwide consideration,” said Dr. Christopher Wild, an oncologist who is IARC director and lead author of the report. “There is now more than sufficient evidence in humans that the consumption of processed meat

Failure in the weeks ahead to reach a budget deal designed to avert automatic spending caps could result in $85 billion inacross-the-board cuts to both military and civilian programs, affecting everything from national parks to student loans early in 2014.
Even worst, Congress could reach these spending levels by once again dragging its feet to pass approval for new government borrowing authority, as was the case in 2011, when gridlock was briefly resolved at the 11th hour. The current borrowing ceiling, through March 2015, would allow almost $4 trillion in debt.

January 15: Congress must pass federal spending measure to avoid snapback in spending on the Pentagon. A previous congressional deficit reduction deal left this spending level flat in 2014 compared to 2013.

21st Feb 2013 at 18:36
I recently saw an article in one of the news magazines stating that games such as Need for Speed and Call of Duty were guilty of causing many young people to become aggressive and in some cases performing criminal acts.

I spent some time on a play.com twitter message board when I saw my first parent notice, saying that this study was conducted on a sample of approximately 2000 people, around the world, who were, they say, not the most well mannered group anyway.

this “yield-compression waterfall” is the extraordinary abundance of capital in developed economies and the low returns on the bond markets in these countries because of their low interest rates.
This means that some conservative investors, such as pension funds that generally have strict risk constraints, are investing in emerging markets. Such investors might feel safer having diversified assets than “balanced portfolios” invested mainly in bonds. A balanced portfolio means a different proportion of assets such as bonds, equities and other diversified global assets, as well as in different investment vehicles such as mutual funds.
One of the areas of emerging market investment that has witnessed an influx of capital from institutional investors is bonds, say fund managers and analysts. Emerging market bonds are seen as more attractive because with their structural imbalances and macroeconomic risks they typically yield substantially more than bonds in developed economies.
In fact, the higher yields make the bonds look value-buying opportunities to investors in both the institutional and retail space, prompting them to invest even in widely diversified mutual funds such

Vail Valley Medical Center announces American Heart Association CPR education certification program
As part of American Heart Month, Vail Valley Medical Center has partnered with the American Heart Association to offer pediatric HeartSaver Certification classes. The class is offered through February and covers proper adult and infant CPR techniques, use of an automated external defibrillator, proper choking relief procedures and Infant/Chilcare CPR. Pedastrian heart attaches of all ages are encouraged to participate.
February marks American Heart Month, when Vail Valley Medical Center and the entire nation focus on the importance of cardiovascular health through official education and awareness programs.
Vail Valley Medical Center will be expanding its existing CPR program to offer certification beyond emergency room personnel to hospital staff and the public.
VVMC has an existing training program for emergency room personnel and will now be extending this training to hospital employees who have children or grandchildren that might be at risk. Classes will be offered three times this week, Wednesday from 9 to

women in the U.S. are dying at fairly high rates seems obscene and indefensible.
The United States has a relatively high maternal mortality rate, compared with other affluent nations, contrary to what I had expected. It's not a very high rate, and the U.S. is not the outlier that, for example, Chad is. But it's the current 4 baby gestation and 4 maternal mortality rates are not actually out facts. In 2009–2013, 734 women died of pregnancy-related complications—on average, 26 pregnant women or mothers died each day during that time period, according to Nowlin and colleagues. That may not sound like a high number because birth rates have declined since 1987; in that year, 1,508 women died during pregnancy or up to one year postpartum, CDC records show. “The window broke 10 metres after the window cleaner finished cleaning and moved on to another window,” one of the passengers told echo, on condition of anonymity. “On the way back in the morning, the window was still broken. It was subsequently repaired.”

We don’t speak about repression enough as a movement on the left, principally because we idealize illusions that “everything is possible.” The fact remains however: every form of organizing carries costs, some more than others, and the danger is that unmaterialized factors constraining the movement indeed constrict it, and narrow its scope of action.
Yes, an elite develops to control an organization; yes, some organizations wane or plainly die, whether from within or without; but, as we all know, others don’t. Yet it’s not enough to say “let’s restructure our already moribund organizations.” Indeed there are many impediments to immigrant organizing today, and no collective has an innate immunity to them. Thus the task is to focus on strategy. There is plenty of the latter’s pillars of thought here and here.
But there’s more. I’ve argued previously here and here that the reform of the immigration issue revolves around three broader questions: Responsibility. Tenability.

MIDDLETOWN, NJ - The Middletown Township Public Library and the Township of Middletown are pleased to announce the appointment of Kim Rinaldi as Provisional Library Director, beginning on February 24, 2014 until March 17, 2014.
The Library Director is appointed by the Township of Middletown.
"I am honored to return to my first library post as Provisional Library Director. Working alongside the staff, the Library Trustees and our resident support base, I look forward to helping the Library community address and overcome new challenges," said Kim Rinaldi.
Kim Rinaldi is currently the Full Time Area Manager for the Monmouth County Library, a position she has held since 2006. Since 2009, she has also worked for Marist College as Adjunct Instructor in Library Science. Previously, she was the Assistant Branch Manager for the Middletown Township Library 2005-06, then Branch Manager for the Altantic Highlands Library 2006-2007. Kim first worked as Library Page for the Middletown Township Library in 1989, branching into circulation, reshelving, computer work, reference, new book reviews, and more.

An eagerly awaited report from the World Health Organization (WHO) states that processed meats such as bacon and sausages cause cancer, and red meat likely does so too.
The France-based International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), part of the WHO, released its third ever report summarizing carcinogenic risks to humans, and included processed meats for the first time.
Processed meats—foods like bacon, ham, sausages, canned meat and some cured meat products—were classified by IARC as “Group 1 Carcinogenic to Humans.” This means that there is strong causal evidence linking them to cancer. Human biomarkers of cancer and exposure data across continents proved this level of risk.
In addition to processed meats, some cooked meats are also proven to be carcinogenic. Red meat products (beef, lamb, pork and veal) were put into “Group 3,” which means IARC lacks evidence linking their ingestion to cancer.
“The IARC classifications bring the global scientific evidence on cancer-causing risks from foods together for worldwide consideration,” said Dr. Christopher Wild, an oncologist who is IARC director and lead author of the report. “There is now more than sufficient evidence in humans that the consumption of processed meat

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew on Sunday warned Congress against manufacturing a crisis over federal spending in the months ahead, as looming deadlines set the stage for a repeat of the political deadlock which two years ago triggered worldwide financial market jitters.
Failure in the weeks ahead to reach a budget deal designed to avert automatic spending caps could result in $85 billion inacross-the-board cuts to both military and civilian programs, affecting everything from national parks to student loans early in 2014.
Even worst, Congress could reach these spending levels by once again dragging its feet to pass approval for new government borrowing authority, as was the case in 2011, when gridlock was briefly resolved at the 11th hour. The current borrowing ceiling, through March 2015, would allow almost $4 trillion in debt.
Some of the key deadlines:
January 15: Congress must pass federal spending measure to avoid snapback in spending on the Pentagon. A previous congressional deficit reduction deal left this spending level flat in 2014 compared to 2013.

NEW YORK — Television retailer QVC has made aggressive plans to keep shoppers watching — instead of mall-hopping — on Black Friday, an event it has traditionally ignored.
The leading network for TV shoppers promises special deals and a healthy dose of new items, including $2,799 DKNY shoes, $1,499 VersaNotes printers and $15 burr coffee grinders.
And there will be some exclusivity: QVC doesn’t carry the iPhone, comparing it to “shopping Evel Knievel,” because its closest competition on Friday will be Best Buy
The approach is laid out in an hourlong TV ad featuring archetypal holiday housewife Betty White with “The National Lampoon Show” star David Cross as her occasionally well-meaning assistant.
It is one way that QVC is seeking to preserve — and survive — as its leading edge of all-day shopping goes head-to-head with the most prolific shopping day of the year in terms of dollars.
“All of a sudden,” QVC and sister cable network HSN CEO Mike George said during an interview. “We decided we should. You’ve Got to Adapt or Die.”

Record low and negative interest rates in developed economies are fueling a ravenous search for yield that is forcing pension funds and other conservative institutional investors out of their comfort zones and into risky emerging markets, according to fund managers and analysts.
The reason for this “yield-compression waterfall” is the extraordinary abundance of capital in developed economies and the low returns on the bond markets in these countries because of their low interest rates.
This means that some conservative investors, such as pension funds that generally have strict risk constraints, are investing in emerging markets. Such investors might feel safer having diversified assets than “balanced portfolios” invested mainly in bonds. A balanced portfolio means a different proportion of assets such as bonds, equities and other diversified global assets, as well as in different investment vehicles such as mutual funds.
One of the areas of emerging market investment that has witnessed an influx of capital from institutional investors is bonds, say fund managers and analysts. Emerging market bonds are seen as more attractive because with their structural imbalances and macroeconomic risks they typically yield substantially more than bonds in developed economies.
In fact, the higher yields make the bonds look value-buying opportunities to investors in both the institutional and retail space, prompting them to invest even in widely diversified mutual funds such

Two UAE orders for military helicopters and guided bombs capped a remarkable year for procurement in which the Emirates became the largest foreign purchaser of US defence equipment, a Pentagon agency said.
The UAE, which has peacekeepers in Afghanistan, awarded Sikorksy Aircraft contracts to convert two of the country’s AH-60 Seahawk helicopters into Sea Hawk heavy lift and coastal patrol-class helicopters for about $54.5 million, the US Defense Security Cooperation Agency said.
The UAE also announced it had agreed to buy 75 Advanced Precision Kill Weapon Systems, developed by Raytheon Corp, for about $148 million in guided bomb-shaped missiles.
That followed previously announced orders for 43 Boeing Super Hornet fighter jets for about $3.3 billion. That, in turn, came on the heels of a $6.8 billion order in 2012 for 25 Lockheed Martin Corp F-16 Super Vipers.
The Defence Security Cooperation Agency must seek Congressional approval for most defence sales of $14 million or more, but the approvals usually are automatic.
Preliminary Defence Department budget documents reveal Saudi Arabia would give Boeing an additional $1.9 billion in contracts for Super Hornet parts while Kuwait would give Lockheed about $700 million in F-16 refurbishment work

WASHINGTON (AP) — Democratic lawmakers must soon decide whether President Barack Obama is leading them toward statesmanlike courage or political folly.
Obama used his first State of the Union speech Wednesday to push nervous Democrats to forge ahead on health care, despite voters’ recent repudiation of the administration’s spending. His expansive, unabashedly liberal message included recognizing gay couples in civil marriages and expanding theouses, and helping low-income people pay for college loans.
Moderates in both parties urged the president to move on, and his political supporters warned him to shift course before his policy initiatives go down as a tragic farce of historic proportions. A statement from House Speaker Nancy Pelosi refused to exclude the White House’s engagement on the energy and climate legislation from this year’s fiscal year agenda.
White House aides believe Obama won political capital for emboldening lawmakers with a message that included a broader definition of family than Republican reservations might allow. They said the speech held together liberals while holding off critics by merely requiring the president to respond if Democrats accused him of being tough in victory and weak in defeat.
“For most senators, the last thing they would reup is getting brought in by Obama,” said Eric Schultz, a White House spokesman.

Robert E. Gates, 65, Altoona, passed away Friday at UPMC Altoona.
Known as Flip, he was born in Massachusetts, son of the late Patricia Gates. He married Cindy Thompson.
Surviving are his wife; two daughters, Linda Edwards, of Altoona, and Lisa Bateski, of Newark; three sons, Jeff Thompson, of Altoona; Mark Gates, of Michigan; and Michael Gates, of NY; a brother, Ed Gates; two sisters, Helen Wynn and Izabelle SanMarino; nine grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.

Vail Valley Medical Center announces American Heart Association CPR education certification program
As part of American Heart Month, Vail Valley Medical Center has partnered with the American Heart Association to offer pediatric HeartSaver Certification classes. The class is offered through February and covers proper adult and infant CPR techniques, use of an automated external defibrillator, proper choking relief procedures and Infant/Chilcare CPR. Pedastrian heart attaches of all ages are encouraged to participate.
February marks American Heart Month, when Vail Valley Medical Center and the entire nation focus on the importance of cardiovascular health through official education and awareness programs.
Vail Valley Medical Center will be expanding its existing CPR program to offer certification beyond emergency room personnel to hospital staff and the public.

Why are American women dying in childbirth?
Maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - except for the United States.
The United States is not the first place that springs to mind when considering women dying in childbirth. So the fact that women in the U.S. are dying at fairly high rates seems obscene and indefensible.
The United States has a relatively high maternal mortality rate, compared with other affluent nations, contrary to what I had expected. It's not a very high rate, and the U.S. is not the outlier that, for example, Chad is. But it's the current 4 baby gestation and 4 maternal mortality rates are not actually out facts. In 2009–2013, 734 women died of pregnancy-related complications—on average, 26 pregnant women or mothers died each day during that time period, according to Nowlin and colleagues. That may not sound like a high number because birth rates have declined since 1987; in that year, 1,508 women died during pregnancy or up to one year postpartum, CDC records show. Women over age 35 fared the worst; among those pregnant women, 12.7 deaths per 100,000 live births

Nike Inc enjoyed big sales in gains in North America and Europe last quarter and benefited from fewer markdowns, helping the maker of sports clothes and shoes report a stronger-than-expected quarterly profit.
Total revenue rose 7.7 percent to $6.955 billion, excluding revenue from its Converse footwear business in China and impacts from changes in foreign currency exchange rates.
The company’s quarterly earnings drop off seasonally as it provides steep discounts to clear old-season sneakers. Reebok was earlier brought down by slumping demand for dressier casual shoes and a wave of markdowns on goods that had piled up in its distribution centers.
Nike said it was on track to meet its 15 percent target for earnings per share for the year, while Reebok’s chief restructuring officer predicted it will at least meet its $0.50 target for the year. Nike’s comparable sales in Europe grew 8 percent in U.S. dollars.

Passengers on an ICE travelling from Berlin to Saarbrücken were shocked after windows were shattered by what they believe were bullets.
Police are investigating after windows on the ICE high-speed train were shattered during the journey from the German capital to Saarbrücken on Saturday night.
The windows broke near the Rhineland city of Trier later that night, after the window cleaner on the train spent 15 minutes working on one of the windows, passengers told echo, the daily newspaper for the state of Saarland.
“The window broke 10 metres after the window cleaner finished cleaning and moved on to another window,” one of the passengers told echo, on condition of anonymity. “On the way back in the morning, the window was still broken. It was subsequently repaired.”
Last month a passenger on a train travelling from Munich to Hamburg found himself hearing gunshots and looking at bullet holes in his coach’s window.
Police said the passenger told them he began to hear shots at about 5.30am, as the train was about to enter the German town of Lohr am Main.
Eyewitnesses said security guards later placed plastic sheeting over the window while talking to the gunman, who was still on the train

The amount is part of the N8.8tn tax revenue needed by the government to finance the 2019 budget.
Details of how the revenue would be generated are contained in the Medium Term Expenditure Framework Tax Revenue Projections for 2019-2021.
If everything goes as projected, the share of tax revenue of the total revenue of the Nigerian economy would increase to 44 percent in 2019 from 43.7 percent in 2017.
The share of taxes will increase marginally to 44.3 percent in 2020.
It will also marginally increase to 43.9 percent in 2021 from 43.7 percent in 2017 resulting to a combined increase of 7.1 percent.
This is the lowest growth rate of tax revenue in the last 30 years since the 1991 fiscal year.
In the last ten years, the growth rate of tax revenue has been going down, compounding the negative impact of declining tax efforts on budget performance.
According to the MTEF, tax revenue is expected to increase to N3.37tn in 2019, N3.5tn in 2020 and N3.56tn by 2021.

WHEN predicting which planets beyond Earth could support life, astronomers usually follow the water. Exoplanets with rocky surfaces are declared habitable if they orbit far enough from their star to potentially host oceans.
But as our planetary collection grows, and telescopes advance to probe more and more planets, previous rules of habitability may be replaced with new ones. That is the suggestion from a newly discovered Earth-sized exoplanet, named Teegarden b.
Its host star is fainter than the Sun and 49 trillion kilometres further away, in the direction of Gemini constellation. As it will take many years of observations to fully study Teegarden b, the possibility of detecting what is actually there yet remains in doubt. But as far as we know, this planet appears to squeeze the limits of habitability.
Researchers consider planets like Teegarden b to be “habitable zone twins” — they are so similar to Earth in terms of distance from their sun-like stars, that astronomers think they should have similar climates. Many in the community might’ve given up the idea of finding such a planet, until now.

Four of the attackers are dead while two suspects are injured by police, along with one civilian, after chasing the van through the streets.
Four years ago in Nice a terrorist drove a lorry into crowds at Bastille Day celebrations. In Germany, Berlin has seen three incidents within the year previous, with one man ramming the Christmas market and two incidents in Berlin earlier this year on New Year's Eve and during the Berlin Pride events.
In the UK, Westminster, London Bridge, London Borough and Borough market have all seen terrifying attacks using vehicles over the past year.
Researchers at the University of Exeter have found that this was the most common method of attack globally last year.
The 'Exeter Index' has found evidence of over 300 vehicle attacks on average per year since 2000, which leaves them as the second highest modus operandi of terrorist attacks, ahead of bombings.

Mattel's Future: Happily Ever After?
Mattel has a plan for the rest of the year, but it seems to be playing a shorter game.
According to its most recent earnings release, Mattel (NASDAQ:MAT) seems to believe that its troubles are over. Segment performance, fixed costs, and segment margin will all improve during the rest of the year "driven by strong gross margin performance."
The problem with Mattel's projections, though, is that there's no indication as to why the company thinks its situation is going to improve. Most gardeners think of diascias as low-growing bedding plants suited to a summer container or the front of a sunny border.
However Diascia personata breaks the mould and produces stiff stems that grow 3ft tall. The substantial bright green stems form a rosette of long green leaves which sit all together at the base of the stems.
1. KEEP THEM DRINKING
The different species have their own quirks and the uprights with small blooms like personata can be unfussy. Gardeners have chosen specific plants to suit rockeries, a foliage plant as ground cover, for a blanket of white blooms or as container specimens with bold orange blooms, and as cut flowers.
‘Personata is a cool grower,’ says Yana Vinichenko of Vanhoutte ‘so I usually grow it from seed to make sure I get big plants all along the ground. They’re quite thirsty and look
dramatic put next to brick.’
The plants, which bloom in late April until the first frosts – as late as November at the Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh where it was introduced in the 1920s by Captain Laurrie Smith, are not prolific but repeat flowering and hardy to -3C

After the wonderful welcome from Julian Clary's dog Valerie, the first thing you notice about his living room is the chickens. There are lots – pictures on the walls, ornaments, even a chicken cushion. "Yes, there's a slight obsession with chickens. I love them," he said. "All I want is to be the posh farmer living in a posh manor."
Clary admits the interiors of his three-bedroom flat in Hampstead and his seafront pad in Brighton are so different, they feel like two different people. "Hampstead is all soft furnishings. It's lovely and cosy," he said. "And Brighton has a sort of nautical feel, a seaside colour-scheme."
Most famously associated with yellow furnishings ("if I'm so famous for nothing, why am I famous for yellow?" he mused), Clary recently made a decision to embrace blue more. "I think yellow suits my personality, and I have ups and downs with colour changes," he explained. "I'm purple when I write, blue when I perform. So now I'm having a blue phase – I feel a bit more stressed in Hampstead, where I really love the yellow... and especially the soft furnishings."

The Airline Vikings were playing for the state football championship in 1972 against Neville on a bad night for football in Monroe.
But after the team had gathered itself, head coach Jack Gray called his seniors together.
Gray, who coached the 2005 Basile boys, had said much the same to his last team at Airline in 2001. The Vikings won the championship that year in a game that set a school attendance record as well.
Saturday's game was only the fifth time ever that Airline and Neville have met.
"You don't meet them very often," says Ron Clark, who went to Airline from 1971-75 and has returned to coaching there. "If you win the game, you get to go downtown on a float and ride through a parade."
As for complaining about the weather, "don't be a baby," Clark said. "Not given this season of highs in the 90s."
For nearly $5,000, Vikings boosters have set up a WeatherPost 300 system at the stadium to control weather on game day. But that has been overridden by this actual weather.

In the summer of 1993, I had one of those experiences that stay with me for the rest of my life.
I spent 10 weeks in Europe, beginning with a six-week law-school summer session at Charles University in Prague.
Prague, that atmospheric, storied, magnificent old city, still so under-the-radar that you could wander off into side streets and find charming little cafes, elegant boutiques and quiet centuries-old churches. It was still Prague way back then, I’d say. (Although I’m no expert, as at that time I had visited only Washington and Mr. Rorshach—the neighborhood from which I fled—and never will be able to say I know a thing about burgundy, not that I’d want to, as wine is a big waste of money these days. Yes, I’m that ugly and awful. Someday you’ll read about me in People magazine.)
With premier Prague purchased, the septet—I like to call my school gang the “Hungory Boys,” its beauty ample but fragile; prone to coughing and retching—packed our bags for a touring jaunt through half-a-dozen other countries.

SANTA FE SPRINGS – A 17-year-old boy died and two men were wounded but expected to survive after a car-to-car shooting on the 5 Freeway late Wednesday, authorities said.
Coroner’s officials did not release the dead boy’s name.
The gunfire erupted in Van Ness Avenue as evening traffic came to a standstill about 11 p.m. It could have been gang-related, Santa Fe Springs police said. Gang investigators were involving throughout the region, the California Highway Patrol and sheriff’s officials said.
A gunman traveling south in the left turn only lane fired several times before fleeing with an accomplice, the CHP estimated.
The boy was behind the wheel of his father’s 2007 Toyota Camry.
“He was lucky one bullet didn’t get through the windshield,” CHP Officer Paulo Ceballos said.
The Toyota’s occupants and possibly the driver of another late-model Mercedes sport-utility vehicle may have exchanges words that prompted the shooting, Ceballos said.
911 callers said the Toyota pulled into the northbound lanes.
“As they were coming back, the person started shooting,” said Michelle Kenney, an LAPD communications officer working the scene.

Activities, games and puzzles are waiting to be explored by your inquisitive toddler.
If you haven’t been to your local library in a while, perhaps it’s time for a visit. Not only can you find there just about any book that you’ve been searching for, but there are many things to keep you and the family occupied.
A visit to the Kingston Frontenac Public Library (KFPL) isn’t just about taking out books.
Last week we visited the Kingston Frontenac Public Library and discovered there are so many things to keep your child engaged while learning: time for storytelling, science activities, puzzles, building blocks and so much more.
The KFPL is not a place we visit every week, however, after seeing all the amazing activities they offer you’d be missing out if you didn’t bring your child! Make it part of your and kids summer routine.
The Assistant Programming co-ordinator, Jen Pelletier, told us to visit the KFPL it’s important always to keep up to date with what’s happening in the library.
During school holidays if you’re in Kingston you may find yourself wondering what to do with the kids during the day. Here’s an option – The K.F.P.L.

Ukraine has started siphoning off Russian gas bound for European customers. This follows the cutoff of gas supplies to Ukraine on January 1, after the two countries’ gas companies failed to agree on a price for 2009.
Gazprom, the main supplier of natural gas to Ukraine from Russia as well as Germany, Italy, France and Greece outright denied that Ukraine, in transit to EU countries, is engaged in illegal activities.
Gazprom’s deputy head, Aleksandr Ryazanov, told a press briefing in Brussels, on January 2 that there are no gas transport anomalies in Ukraine, as Russia continues to supply gas via Ukraine to EU countries. “In Ukraine, at present, gas transit is proceeding along its normal routes,” he said. “Although gas suppliers have refused to pay over 60 million cubic meters of gas, gas transit continues to proceed without misfortune.” Gazprom representatives said the talks with the Naftogaz are continuing.
Naftogaz company announced it intends to siphon off each week an amount of gas corresponding to 12.5 million cubic meters of its own gas consumption.

The Eagles, after trading LeSean McCoy to the Buffalo Bills, might have found his replacement.
A person with knowledge of the situation, who requested anonymity, told NJ Advance Media that the Eagles have expressed interest in free-agent running back Frank Gore.
Gore has spent the last 11 seasons with the San Francisco 49ers, and given the current uncertainty surrounding the Niners' running back situation, the Birds could have interest in signing the veteran to a one-year deal. It would not be surprising to see the Eagles pursue Gore in light of Kansas City's splurge on running back Carlos Hyde.
Gore, 34, has carried the ball 2,585 times in his career for 9,789 yards and 49 touchdowns, along with 814 catches for 6,963 yards and 33 receiving touchdowns -- while compiling just one career fumble. He's never been charged with a rush fumble. The 49ers sent Gore to the Philadelphia Eagles and Baltimore Ravens in the discarded draft pick swap last September.

GENEVA, Mar 18 2013 (IPS) - The current growth model is not sustainable. Neither the green economy nor alternative sources of energy can prevent global warming. Solutions will come from concerted actions at the local and national levels, the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD), and an expert group in the field of sustainable development say.
The U.N.’s historic Rio+20 conference that was held last June in Brazil warned that unless world leaders agree on the implementation of a comprehensive plan to combat climate change, indications are that emissions will far surpass the limit set by the 2009 Copenhagen agreement.
This deadline is 2020 and involves an 80 percent reduction of greenhouse gases, one of the targets of the U. N.’s Millennium Development Goals (MDG).
The result is that if strong action is not taken, the planet Earth is at risk of becoming a place that is no longer fit for human habitation. Species are going extinct at a faster rate than at any time in the last 60 million years.

The federal government is accelerating Canada’s transition to a lower-carbon economy, even as conservative politicians in the provinces vow to scuttle key measures that would support that effort.
Natural Resources Minister Jim Carr endorsed an advisory council report Thursday that spells out an ambitious agenda for Canada’s energy market to meet the emissions reduction targets set under the Paris Climate Accord.
The report, “It’s Time: Clean Growth Action Plan for the Canadian Energy Sector,” sets out a vision of an energy sector that continues to produce essential oils, fuels and electricity for the upcoming decades, but does so without growing Canada’s emissions further. It said that would mean 57 per cent cuts from the electricity generation sector, the near elimination of methane gas leaks from the oil and gas sector, and continued improvements in fuel efficiencies for both conventional vehicles and electric-vehicles by 2030.
It also has no misgivings that Canada will have to join a system in which there is a price placed on greenhouse emissions. That’s notable, given that Ontario just axed its mandatory cap-and-trade regime, imposed by the former Liberal government, as Alberta starts to rally and expand its own pricing system.
Canada is already moving in that direction. The price in Alberta falls next month. B

Smartphones can play a very positive role as a new tool with ophthalmologists, shows a new study conducted by the Emory University.
Smartphones can be extensively used by ophthalmologists for viewing complex inner eye photos for diagnostic purpose. They have also made measurements of the angle between the white part of the eye and iris of the colored part. This particular measurements are used as a disease marker of raised eye pressure. The photographs are as good as standard equipment but at lower cost. Behavioral tips are also used by clinicians to take pictures by their patients at home, show symptoms of the disease during latest incursions. Smartphones are essentially smartphones that help tap the potential of high-quality cameras have high-definition details.
"Smartphone imaging allows ophthalmologists to interact with the patients and view real-time evidence of the disease" says Francesco Oddo, MD, professor of ophthalmology at the department of ophthalmology and researcher at the Emory Eye Center. "This helps physicians better educate the patients and track progression of their eye diseases," Dr.Oddo adds.

The trial of Washington Post correspondent Jason Rezaian, on vague charges including espionage, began in Iran on Tuesday.
On Tuesday, the trial of Washington Post reporter Jason Rezaian, who has been imprisoned for nearly 10 months in Iran on espionage charges, began inside the Iran Revolutionary Court.
Rezaian pleaded not guilty, his attorney Leila Amini said, in a tweet following the first hearing.
More than two-dozen people reportedly attended the hearing, including Mina Rezaian, Jason’s sister, who tweeted, “Thankfully, our family has been granted permission to attend today’s hearing and we are asking the international community for its support.”
The United Nations Secretary General Antonio Guterres and the U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry have already issued public pleas for Rezaian’s release.
Amini, an Iranian attorney, said that she believes Rezaian could be sentenced to 20 years in prison.

California is lifting its drought emergency for most of the state after a winter of record rain and snowfall that followed a five-year dry spell.
Gov. Jerry Brown's office announced Friday that his executive order will lift the drought emergency in California, except for a portion of the state near Lake Oroville, the state’s second largest reservoir. Brown has lifted or modified the drought emergency seven times since declaring a drought state of emergency in 2014.
The revision for Lake Oroville means that officials will continue to use water conservation practices, but water resources will be managed without the declared drought emergency.
“California is enjoying a year of extraordinary rainfall and snowfall as we continue to leave our five-year drought behind, and California is now in the midst of the wettest period it has experienced since records began,” the governor’s office sai. “The Department of Water Resources projects that statewide January-June runoff will be the greatest in wet years on record, and nearly twice the average of wet years.” [Read more at our sister site, KQED Science. ]

CHICAGO -- A three-year-old boy died after a fire swept through his South Side home Sunday, police said.
Firefighters arrived at the three-story building on the 6700 block of South Dorchester Avenue two minutes after receiving calls of smoke coming from the block and found a fire in an apartment on the second floor.
Moments later, a body was pulled from the second floor by firefighters to the third floor and rushed to the University of Chicago Medical Center, said department spokesman Robert Quinn.
The body of the toddler who lived in the apartment, Baraka Lansick, was found inside. He had been there with his cousin, 9, who suffered injuries to his hands, said Quinn.
Family members told FIRE BLOG CHICAGO  a fire engine from neighboring Roseland did not show up during the incident and can be seen in the video above. Fire department spokesman Robert Quinn said the Roseland fire engine was but quickly redirected to another fire in the neighborhood. He said Roseland units do not respond to calls outside of the Roseland Fire District.
Quinn also told FIRE BLOG CHICAGO that the call regarding smoke was canceled after the department determined it was not necessary.

As I alluded to previously, immigration reform seems to me like an issue where radical tactics, if people could be organized to engage in them, would have high prospects for success. Among other things, Jose Antonio Vargas’ story today makes that obvious. We don’t speak about repression enough as a movement on the left, principally because we idealize illusions that “everything is possible.” The fact remains however: every form of organizing carries costs, some more than others, and the danger is that unmaterialized factors constraining the movement indeed constrict it, and narrow its scope of action.
Yes, an elite develops to control an organization; yes, some organizations wane or plainly die, whether from within or without; but, as we all know, others don’t. Yet it’s not enough to say “let’s restructure our already moribund organizations.” Indeed there are many impediments to immigrant organizing today, and no collective has an innate immunity to them. Thus the task is to focus on strategy. There is plenty of the latter’s pillars of thought here and here.
But there’s more. I’ve argued previously here and here that the reform of the immigration issue revolves around three broader questions: Responsibility. Tenability.

IF you like cricket, and like a brainy writer whose intellectualism is friendly and endearing, you’d better read this book. Mike Brearley was a cricketer with modest abilities, but he possesses a beautiful mind. Most creditable – and amusing – of all the cricket books I’ve ever read, the cricket in this weighty little thing is like a kind of Prolog, whereby you need to load the device before it can drive the contents. Everybody (you assume) has always been fascinated by how it is that spectators reportedly bond with the personalities of top players; a trait that can stay with a person long after their involvement ceases. Tricks of the Mind seeks to explain it fully – and with style. Raised when people thought and humoured with people as they now think and humour with themselves, cricket’s hitherto unconquered mystery is finally uncovered. It’s almost a wonder how it’s not a fizzing Minitel frenzy of a bestseller. (Maybe not.) Unlikely, though, famous book – I’d guess. Which is undoubtedly why you’d remember it. Worth mentioning, too, is that the book is sponsored, and the ad-space is handled in style by Lombardo Piş

Content protection features in Windows Vista are preventing customers from playing high-quality video and audio and harming system performance, even as Microsoft neglects security programs that could protect users, computer researcher Peter Gutmann argued at the USENIX Security Symposium in Boston Wednesday.
gutman Having first tackled Gutmann on video quality and file-encrypting technology earlier this week, today Jack Clark points out that Microsoft's content protection scheme allows for an additional level of getContentURL() on top of something like a Java script, much like the ASR loader does.
By running a poisoned contentURL of something like "javascript://alert('attacking computer')", Windows Vista can be exploited to launch any application an attacker can posit on a user's system. This is what Jerry Bowman discovered independently of Peter Gutmann's work (come up with a better username!) earlier this year.
Microsoft's Ian Hardy was quick to take Gutmann to task saying that some content is protected with multiple layers of protection, including hardware-based digital rights management. Heat up the pellets! The question, however, is why content operators would want to narrow their audience pool when their content is now basically self-protected on multiple levels? The scene of the fatal stabbing of a man in his 60’s at a house on Rutland Grove, Crumlin at about 8pm last night. Photograph: Colin Keegan/ Collins Dublin.
A man in is 60s has been stabbed to death in what is believed to have been a feud-related killing last night in Dublin.
The murder happened at a house in Rutland Grove, Crumlin around 8.30pm.
A post mortem revealed the fatal blow was dealt from behind while the man was seated on the couch.
Just over 24 hours earlier, the alleged perpetrator - a man in his 30s - was in the same house as neighbours held firecrackers to his ears as a sort of vigilante punishment for his alleged crimes.
That man is currently in custody and being questioned about yesterday’s killing.
Up to now, Gardaí have been unable to explain what sequence of events led to the fatal stabbing.

HELENA – A state panel heard four hours of testimony Wednesday on bills relating to missing and murdered Indigenous women, an issue that proponents said affect all Montanans, but could have a profound impact on the Native American community.
House Bill 219 posed the most difficult choices for both sponsors and witnesses.
It would extend the statute of limitations for a number of felonies against Native women, including sexual assault, rape and eliminating the deadline to file a report when crimes are committed through intimidation or threats of violence.
Supporters pointed out that Montana’s statute of limitations protects men from prosecution until DNA evidence is found, but for women, the clock starts ticking the day they report the crime, often many years later due to the trauma they experience.
Caitlin Burbridge, director of Montana’s Office of Teacher Certification, is part of the Master of Public Health program at the University of Montana. She said research indicates the behaviors affected by the statistical average age an abuse victim is when she reports the incident can mean a woman between 50 and 75. That not only changes the stories a woman may offer, but the witnesses the woman would call.

New Delhi: FMCG major Hindustan Unilever (HUL) on Thursday reported a 9 per cent increase in its net profit to Rs 1,444 crore for the December 2018 quarter on account of strong volume growth and improved margins.
The company had posted a net profit of Rs 1,323 crore in the same quarter last fiscal, HUL said in a statement.
Quarterly revenue from operations grew at a rate of 5 per cent at Rs 6,420 crore, when compared to the same period last fiscal. EBIT was at Rs 1,653 crore in the said quarter, which is an increase of 17 per cent from last year, the company said in a statement. EBIT margin expanded by 180 basis points to 26 per cent led by improved gross margin, lower other expenses and higher pricing.

PARIS (Reuters) - Finding friends and meeting new ones could become even more important uses for global positioning chips than getting from A to B as the technology spreads to cellphones in coming years.
Combined with mobile Internet access, GPS (global positioning system) technology in the mobile phones of 10 or 15 years' time could mean that people would automatically log the places and meeting times of all their contacts and friends, a founder of a new ventures group at mobile giant Nokia (NOK) predicted.
This could block nuisances such as receiving a "come visit me" text message only to find that one's invited location had vanished.
"It could be quite irritating if I sent you a place and you get a message back saying their coverage is really bad at the moment so they can't tell you where they are but let me know when you're at such and such place," said University of Cambridge engineering colleague Phil James.
"We would integrate (mobile phone to cellphone) contacts through almost relentless add-ons, almost invisibly, not really saying what was happening...but in that process picking up incredibly useful knowledge about what we were doing," he said at a recent Reuters journalists' seminar in Paris.
"You will be tracking me across the world like dust

The Transformative Fund Account formed 18 months ago at the Central Bank of Kenya to hold proceeds from the voluntary pay cuts has only Sh35.2 million.
Super salary-scale civil servants are ceding only Sh2 million per month to the Treasury from their annual salary supplements totalling Sh109 million, data from the Treasury show.
The amount could be higher as some departments of government, including the Judiciary and the Executive, are yet to finalise the implementation of Sh90,000 salary supplements for each worker including President Uhuru Kenyatta and Deputy President William Ruto.
Even before the monthly voluntary increments are implemented for each worker totalling Sh140 million, a significant part of the annual contribution has been taken off for next year’s salary negotiations with the protagonists.
The results of the annual salary review recommended Sh21,000 per civil servant against the Kenya Civil Servants Union proposal of Sh50,000.
Instead of the 15 per cent pay increment, the Treasury will only have about Sh112 million to distribute among recipients recommended in the roadmap of the Upper salary Scheme  taken as approved as of January.

To help solve this problem, Andrew Foote and Emily Woods started Sanivation— No. 55 on the BI 100: The Creators — a sanitation startup that installs in-home toilets in East Africa and turns the waste into briquettes, which the company sells to briquette manufacturers.
“People were throwing away their poop, leaving their families, their grandparents, people vulnerable to cholera and diarrhea,” Foote said. “We want universal health care, and door-to-door sanitation, like vaccinations, is part of that.”
Foote spent seven years in Kenya working for Ventures Consulting, an incubator for business in Africa. When he helped one of its clients bring a sanitation system to Kenya, Foote realized its potential for a global impact. With Woods— an engineering graduate of Cambridge University and a Gates Cambridge Scholar — he started Sanivation.
To date, the company has installed over 2,000 toilets in Nairobi and Kampala. The urine and fecal waste is turned into briquettes for a burnable fuel. Every 6 months a customer pays the Kenya-based company directly for a monthly toilet subscription fee and a delivery service.

Dhanaraj was charged with one count of aggravated child abuse after the video was presented by detectives with the department’s respect, ethics and integrity unit. Dhanaraj was viewing pornography on her cellphone while the child fidgeted nearby. Dhanaraj allegedly rubbed her crotch, breasts and buttocks. Similar videos discovered on Dhanaraj’s phone allegedly showed her rubbing the head of an erect male sexual organ on videos of young girls.

Students have long applied to colleges and universities with applications that are heavy on test scores and grades. While that's not necessarily wrong, the founders of ZeeMee believe it doesn't tell the whole story. This Redwood City, California-based startup believes in the social network. And specifically in a social network that college-bound students can use to share the real stuff that doesn't necessarily pop on a GPA report or a transcript.
"The whole idea of ZeeMee was that we were students like most college-bound teenagers," said Brian Chen, one of the company's two co-founder. "We were approaching college, we were going through the traditional application process, and we realized there was a huge gap between the way we described ourselves on paper and the way everyone else described us. You know, college admissions officers and all our peers, people who really knew us would give you a completely different review."
ZeeMee is currently on MIT Reverse Pitch Class 12-13.

agencies at the local, state and federal level all employ marketing professionals in areas including, but not limited to, public relations, property disposal, bond sales and purchasing.
Almost all major government agencies have their own public-relations staff, and in many cases it is a stand-alone department with a public relations or media director and several support staff. Government agency PR departments are responsible for producing news releases, holding press conferences, and generally promoting activities of the agency, such as tourism or encouraging new businesses to move into the area.
Government agencies are constantly buying supplies, equipment and other property and selling off old equipment and property. The departments tasked with disposing of this government property often hire individuals with a background in marketing. Their job is to assist the agency in coming up with creative ways to sell or otherwise dispose of obsolete government property.
Most government agencies have to follow complicated regulations for purchasing supplies and equipment. In many cases, agencies can only buy from certain suppliers or can only buy goods within specific price ranges. Agencies

the WHO, put processed meats on the top of their “things that cause cancer list”, grouping them alongside tobacco, asbestos and diesel fumes, for which there is “sufficient evidence” of cancer links.
Along the years, there have been many studies that linked processed and red meats with cancer (especially bowel cancer), but there were always some doubts floating about. Now, the 22-member panel analyzed animal experiments, studies of human diet and health, and cell mechanisms that could lead from these meats to cancer.
“These findings further support current public health recommendations to limit intake of meat,” Dr. Christopher Wild, who directs IARC, said in a statement.
The decision wasn’t unanimous though, and a “probably” still crept in to the report. Many studies show the links, both in populations of people and in tests that show how eating these foods can cause cancer, the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) said in its report, released in the Lancet medical journal.

In coming negotiations with Republicans, who control the House of Representatives, Democratic President Barack Obama will focus on ways to create economic gains for the middle class over spending cuts, Lew said.
“We have already done a lot of deficit reduction,” he said in an interview on NBC. Lew spoke on four TV talk shows, setting out Obama’s priorities ahead of an expected showdown this fall.
By early November, Congress must raise the legal limit on the country’s borrowing authority or risk an unprecedented default on the government’s debt.
A debt ceiling showdown in August 2011 between Obama and congressional Republicans sparked wild stock market swings and cost the United States its top-tier AAA credit rating.
“We need to get the debt limit extended in a way that doesn’t create a crisis,” Lew said.
Republicans see the debt ceiling as the their best leverage in winning a deal with Obama that would cut federal government spending to lower the deficit.

of diarrhea. There are also some foods to avoid when dealing with a bout of diarrhea, and some additional home care tips to consider.
Anyone who is experiencing persistent diarrhea should see a doctor, as a person may become dehydrated over time.
Diarrhea is a bowel movement that is more liquid than solid or has a loose texture. It is a common problem and may occur a couple of times each year. Diarrhea will usually last no more than 3 days.
Soft, bland foods, such as toast, will help to absorb excess water and ease the symptoms of diarrhea.
People with chronic digestive conditions, such as irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) or Crohn's disease, may experience diarrhea more regularly.
A person's diet is crucial if they are experiencing diarrhea. Some foods might help relieve symptoms of diarrhea while eating other foods can make diarrhea worse.
While recovering from diarrhea, a person should eat bland, simple foods that are easy to digest and will help absorb some water from

The force propelling pension funds and insurance companies into unfamiliar EM investments is simple. If they stay at home, their investment returns are at risk of falling short of their liabilities.
"If you require, say, 5 percent a year in order to cover your insurance or pension liabilities, that is not available from developed market (debt) obviously," said Colm McDonagh, head of emerging market fixed income at Insight Investment.
Brett Diment, head of emerging market debt at Aberdeen Asset Management, also sees a diversification into EM debt by pension and insurance companies. "We are seeing a broader group of investors looking at the emerging market debt asset class, including some insurers and pension funds that have not looked before."

Nevada's effective monopoly on sports betting ended last spring, when the Supreme Court ruled the ban should be lifted. Casinos in seven other states — Rhode Island, Delaware, Mississippi, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, West Virginia and New Mexico — now accept wagers on sports. The list is expected to grow by next year with numerous states considering bills.
And there's already a hitch that could slow bets: NASCAR this season has decided for the first time to strip drivers of victories if their cars are deemed illegal. There will be a roughly 90-minute inspection after the race and the winner will not be deemed official until the process is completed. Will fans really want to linger around the pay window another couple of hours just to cash in a ticket?
"The state's risk manager will delay any payout until NASCAR releases the official order of finish," Kirk said.

"We need to think about how to not just do good for ourselves, but also for future generations.

On Valentine’s Day 2007, Lynn Blake was embarking on a new job in Vail Village when she had a rude awakening. The 27-year-old suffered sudden cardiac arrest. Fortunately for her, someone trained in CPR stepped forward and kept her heart beating until emergency personnel arrived with a defibrillator. If someone dropped in front of you unconscious, with no notable pulse, would you know what to do? Some 325,000 people die every year of sudden cardiac arrest (SCA) in the United States. And, contrary to popular belief, it strikes people of all ages. “I did not know a thing about cardiac arrest. I didn’t know what it was,” Blake said. Now she knows firsthand about sudden cardiac arrest. The more she found out, the more she wondered why more people weren’t educated about SCA, the leading causes of death in the U.S. Just a few months after Blake’s sudden cardiac

two American women die of pregnancy-related causes every day may come as a surprise.
According to the World Bank, The US ranks 50th in maternal mortality globally - falling behind every other industrialised nation. A woman in the US is as likely to suffer a maternal death as a woman in sanctions-hit Iran, and four times as likely as a woman in Germany.
"It is a preventable health issue," said Amnesty International's Rachel Ward. "It isn't something that we're waiting for a cure for. We’re waiting for political will."
What's worse is that US maternal mortality rates may actually be on the rise. Eugene Declercq, of Boston University's School of Public Health, produced a short film named Birth by the numbers, discussing maternal mortality in the US. In a 2013 follow-up report, he noted how mortality rates in other industrialised nations had declined - but in the US, it increased by 30 percent in the first decade of the new millennium.

It’s not the food—the grub is OK, if not exactly slimming; it’s the gas generators powering the carts. Most food carts run off a diesel generator that’s designed to run only a few hours. Vendors run them for stretches of up to 14 hours, leading to a high output of greenhouse-gas emissions such as carbon monoxide, nitrous oxide, and particulate matter. You can see the smoke with the naked eye, but the hard facts are even more frightening: The research and consulting firm Energy Vision found that each cart produces the same amount of nitrous oxide as 186 cars on the road.

In its milestone report, “The Limits to Growth”, published in 1972, the Club of Rome warned that the human ecological footprint had grown dangerously quickly from 1900 to 1972. Shortly thereafter, the warning proved to be prophetic: by 1986 the human ecological footprint had overshot the carrying capacity of the Earth. At current production and consumption levels, we need 1.5 planets to survive; if everyone lived like a U.S. citizen, we would need five planets.
Land, water and biodiversity continue to decline. Global CO2 emissions are on the rise. The oceans are warming and the sea level is rising continuously. Forest cover has decreased by 300 million hectares since 1990.

The study was conducted among some 350 patients who reported issues like headaches, eyesight changes and similar vision problems in emergency rooms.
The study also included the inner-eye photos taken by the ER staff using an ocular camera.
Then the study team assessed the response of two ophthalmologists who viewed and rated the pictures on a desktop PC and did the same on an iPhone.
The results of the study, published in the Archives of Ophthalmology, show that the doctors found the iPhone images good or better than desktop images and rated them high.
While one ophthalmologist felt 53 pictures were of the same quality, he found 46 better on iPhone and just one was better on PC.
For the other ophthalmologist who participated in the study, 56 were of equal quality, while 42 were better on iPhone leaving only two better on PC.

many celebrated breakthroughs were initially met with scorn and ridicule. We've compiled 11 such world-famous ideas from the history of science and technology. The temptation, of course, is to include those ideas that were scorned and should have stayed scorned. The Star Wars prequels, say. But we're trying to run a classy operation here.
Heliocentrism Galileo Galilei, sometimes called the Father of Modern Science, was among the first and most famous to pay a price for his crazy scientific ideas. Galileo publicly promoted the Copernican concept of heliocentrism -- that the Earth revolves around the Sun -- back when the Church and even most fellow mathematicians held to geocentric model. Unfortunately, in 17th century Rome, such radical ideas were quite literally heresy. Galileo was forced to recant and spend the rest of his life under house arrest.

While Microsoft's intent is to protect commercial content, home movies are increasingly being shot in high definition, Gutmann said. Many users are finding they can't play any content if it's considered "premium."

IBM on Tuesday announced a prepackaged and pretested cluster that is powered by Advanced Micro Devices Inc.s 64-bit Opteron processor.
IBM, of Armonk, N.Y., is combining its Opteron-based eServer 325 server—which targets scientific and technical computing users—with systems management software and storage devices to offer a bundled package that can run Linux and Windows operating systems.
The new offering, which will be available later this month or in early December, is part of IBMs eServer Cluster 1350, which also includes bundles based on the companys BladeCenter blade servers and two-processor x335 and x345 systems using Intel Corp.s 32-bit Xeon chips.
Clusters comprise multiple servers tied together to create a supercomputing environment for users. In a related move, IBM last week announced that it was teaming with Corning Inc., the U.S. Department of Energy and the National Nuclear Security Administration to develop high-speed, optically switched interconnects for supercomputers. Marketers are employed in the public sector as well as the private sector.
Most people think of marketing as a strictly private sector activity, but the reality is people with sales and marketing backgrounds are hired by government agencies in a number of capacities. Government agencies at the local, state and federal level all employ marketing professionals in areas including, but not limited to, public relations, property disposal, bond sales and purchasing.
Almost all major government agencies have their own public-relations staff, and in many cases it is a stand-alone department with a public relations or media director and several support staff. Government agency PR departments are responsible for producing news releases, holding press conferences, and generally promoting activities of the agency, such as tourism or encouraging new businesses to move into the area.
Government agencies are constantly buying supplies, equipment and other property and selling off old equipment and property. The departments tasked with disposing of this government property often hire individuals with a background in marketing. Their job is to assist the agency in coming up with creative ways to sell or otherwise dispose of obsolete government property.
Most government agencies have to follow complicated regulations for purchasing supplies and equipment. In many cases, agencies can only buy from certain suppliers or can only buy goods within specific price ranges. Agencies

MIDDLETOWN, NJ - The Middletown Township Public Library and the Township of Middletown are pleased to announce the appointment of Kim Rinaldi as Provisional Library Director, beginning on February 24, 2014. Ms. Rinaldi will earn a salary of $95,000.00 per year.
Ms. Rinaldi comes to the Middletown Township Public Library after having served as the Library Director of the Margaret E. Heggen Free Public Library in Washington Township, New Jersey. During her tenure in Washington Township, Ms. Rinaldi managed 26 employees and a $2.5 million annual budget. Ms. Rinaldi has also served as the Director of the Brielle Public Library and as a Senior Librarian at the Ocean County Library, Long Beach Island Branch in Surf City, New Jersey.
Ms. Rinaldi holds a Masters in Library and Information Science from Texas Women’s College and has extensive experience in library administration, budgeting and project management. Ms. Rinaldi is credited with outsourcing material cataloging and processing at the Margaret E. Heggan Free Public Library, reducing annual operating costs by $150,000.00. Ms. Rinaldi

An eagerly awaited report from the World Health Organization (WHO) states that processed meats such as bacon and sausages cause cancer, and red meat likely does so too.
The France-based International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), part of the WHO, put processed meats on the top of their “things that cause cancer list”, grouping them alongside tobacco, asbestos and diesel fumes, for which there is “sufficient evidence” of cancer links.
Along the years, there have been many studies that linked processed and red meats with cancer (especially bowel cancer), but there were always some doubts floating about. Now, the 22-member panel analyzed animal experiments, studies of human diet and health, and cell mechanisms that could lead from these meats to cancer.
“These findings further support current public health recommendations to limit intake of meat,” Dr. Christopher Wild, who directs IARC, said in a statement.
The decision wasn’t unanimous though, and a “probably” still crept in to the report. Many studies show the links, both in populations of people and in tests that show how eating these foods can cause cancer, the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) said in its report, released in the Lancet medical journal.

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew on Sunday warned Congress against manufacturing a crisis over federal spending in the months ahead, as looming deadlines set the stage for a repeat of the political deadlock which two years ago triggered worldwide financial market turmoil.
In coming negotiations with Republicans, who control the House of Representatives, Democratic President Barack Obama will focus on ways to create economic gains for the middle class over spending cuts, Lew said.
“We have already done a lot of deficit reduction,” he said in an interview on NBC. Lew spoke on four TV talk shows, setting out Obama’s priorities ahead of an expected showdown this fall.
By early November, Congress must raise the legal limit on the country’s borrowing authority or risk an unprecedented default on the government’s debt.
A debt ceiling showdown in August 2011 between Obama and congressional Republicans sparked wild stock market swings and cost the United States its top-tier AAA credit rating.
“We need to get the debt limit extended in a way that doesn’t create a crisis,” Lew said.
Republicans see the debt ceiling as the their best leverage in winning a deal with Obama that would cut federal government spending to lower the deficit.
Lew, who was Obama’s budget director in 2011, reiterated the president

In case you missed it, the initials ICYMI stand for the first five words of this sentence. In the event you have, indeed, missed it (ITEYH, I, MI has not taken off yet for some reason), it’s most likely because you’re not on the Internet much, particularly Twitter, where individuals and outlets deploy it every few seconds to bring links to the attention of others who may not have seen them. The New York Times now even has a section at the bottom of its app called “In Case You Missed It” with articles from previous days.
While the extended phrase has been used in conversation for a long time, the shorthand betrays an anxiety central to the Internet epoch. There is simply too much readable, viewable and listenable data for anyone to stay abreast of, as a humor piece, “I’m All Caught Up!” by Nick Mickowski in McSweeney’s, playfully suggested.

NEW YORK — Television retailer QVC has made aggressive plans to keep shoppers watching — instead of mall-hopping — on Black Friday, an event it has traditionally ignored.
The leading network for TV shoppers promises special deals and a healthy dose of new items for sale starting on Thanksgiving night. Program host Dave James plans to stay awake for 28 hours of telethon-like coverage.
The day after Thanksgiving is traditionally the biggest shopping day of the year, called “Black Friday” because it’s key for many businesses to go in the black, or turn a profit. QVC, which competes with ShopNBC and the HSN home shopping network, has not wanted to get caught up in the frenzy and has always treated it as just another day for its sales pitches, said Doug Rose, the network’s vice president of programming and marketing.
“This year, and we’ve been planning on this for many months, we really expect to join the fray with the other retailers,” Rose said.

Occasional diarrhea is a common occurrence. Most people will experience an episode of diarrhea at least once or twice a year that will disappear in a couple of days.
Luckily, there are many foods to eat that may help a person reduce the symptoms of diarrhea. There are also some foods to avoid when dealing with a bout of diarrhea, and some additional home care tips to consider.
Anyone who is experiencing persistent diarrhea should see a doctor, as a person may become dehydrated over time.
Diarrhea is a bowel movement that is more liquid than solid or has a loose texture. It is a common problem and may occur a couple of times each year. Diarrhea will usually last no more than 3 days.
Soft, bland foods, such as toast, will help to absorb excess water and ease the symptoms of diarrhea.
People with chronic digestive conditions, such as irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) or Crohn's disease, may experience diarrhea more regularly.
A person's diet is crucial if they are experiencing diarrhea. Some foods might help relieve symptoms of diarrhea while eating other foods can make diarrhea worse.

Record low and negative interest rates in developed economies are fueling a ravenous search for yield that is forcing pension funds and other conservative institutional investors out of their comfort zones and into risky emerging markets, according to fund managers and analysts.
The reason for this has little to do with the attractiveness of EM investments. On the contrary, EM economic growth is at its lowest level since the 2008/09 financial crisis while the prospect of a U.S. monetary tightening creates the potential for financial turbulence.
The force propelling pension funds and insurance companies into unfamiliar EM investments is simple. If they stay at home, their investment returns are at risk of falling short of their liabilities.
"If you require, say, 5 percent a year in order to cover your insurance or pension liabilities, that is not available from developed market (debt) obviously," said Colm McDonagh, head of emerging market fixed income at Insight Investment.
Brett Diment, head of emerging market debt at Aberdeen Asset Management, also sees a diversification into EM debt by pension and insurance companies. "We are seeing a broader group of investors looking at the emerging market debt asset class, including some insurers and pension funds that have not looked before."
Much of this search for yield

Two UAE orders for military helicopters and guided bombs capped a remarkable year for procurement in which the Emirates became the largest foreign purchaser of US defence equipment, a Pentagon agency said.
The UAE, which has peacekeepers in Afghanistan, awarded Sikorksy Aircraft a US$171 million (Dh628m) contract for 14 UH-60 Black Hawk helicopters, which are used for tactical transport.
Separately, the US defence security co-operation agency, a unit of the Pentagon, said last week it had notified Congress of a potential sale of enhanced guided bomb units, parts, training and support to the UAE for about $290m.
The same agency said in November that in the last fiscal year the UAE became the largest foreign purchaser of US defence equipment with sales of $7.9bn, ahead of Afghanistan ($5.4bn), Saudi Arabia ($3.3bn) and Taiwan ($3.2bn).
The spending included orders for munitions for the UAE’s F-16 fighter jets as well as a new Patriot defensive missile system and a fleet of corvettes for the navy.

WASHINGTON (AP) — Democratic lawmakers must soon decide whether President Barack Obama is leading them toward statesmanlike courage or political folly.
Obama used his first State of the Union speech Wednesday to push nervous Democrats to forge ahead on health care, despite voters' worries and opposition from newly strengthened Republicans. Sharpening his focus on the economy, he offered a hodgepodge of tax breaks and other incentives to create new jobs.
For Republicans, Obama blended a mix of overtures and digs. But he mainly addressed fellow Democrats, who still can enact his agenda if they overcome fears fueled by events such as last week's stunning GOP victory in the Massachusetts Senate race.
That setback may have cost Democrats their filibuster-proof Senate majority, Obama said, but "we still have the largest majority in decades, and the people expect us to solve some problems, not run for the hills."
He accepted partial blame for the deep troubles facing his health care push, but he implored lawmakers to finish the task rather than yield to public opposition.

Lynn Blake, left, teaches two hospital employees CPR at the VVMC Safety Fair. Blakeâs passion for educating Eagle County residents came from her own Sudden Cardiac Arrest, which a bystander provided CPR and saved her life. She was just 27 at the time.
On Valentine’s Day 2007, Lynn Blake was embarking on a new job in Vail Village when she had a rude awakening. The 27-year-old suffered sudden cardiac arrest. Fortunately for her, someone trained in CPR stepped forward and kept her heart beating until emergency personnel arrived with a defibrillator. If someone dropped in front of you unconscious, with no notable pulse, would you know what to do? Some 325,000 people die every year of sudden cardiac arrest (SCA) in the United States. And, contrary to popular belief, it strikes people of all ages. “I did not know a thing about cardiac arrest. I didn’t know what it was,” Blake said. Now she knows firsthand about sudden cardiac arrest. The structural budget position is defined as the actual budget deficit (or surplus) less the effects of cyclical deviations of output from potential output. Because of the margin of uncertainty that attaches to estimates of cyclical gaps and to tax and expenditure elasticities with respect to national income, indicators of structural budget positions should be interpreted as broad orders of magnitude.

After competing many times, local artist Ann Iungerich and her husband, David, decided to share some lessons learned Saturday in an ice-sculpting workshop.
The concept was more sculptors might make for a better competition.
"We've done a lot of research and tried to figure out what's what. That was why we decided to have a workshop - what few little secrets we know, we're willing to share that with others," Ann explained.
Ann and David Iungerich taught the half dozen participants how to chop away at the ice, just using wood chisels.
"Over the years, we've learned that just wood chisels work the best for us," Ann said. "We don't bring any power tools. We just have different various sharp chisels and that's what we use."
There's typically six to eight teams each year, and the Iungerichs are hoping this workshop will expand involvement and break down the barrier for people who may be interested in competing themselves.
Although she is an artist in many other mediums herself, Ann says she had never sculpted ice before her first year. After a friend suggested she try it, Ann said, "Sure!"

Why are American women dying in childbirth?
Maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - except for the United States.
The United States is not the first place that springs to mind when considering women dying in childbirth. So the fact that two American women die of pregnancy-related causes every day may come as a surprise.
According to the World Bank, The US ranks 50th in maternal mortality globally - falling behind every other industrialised nation. A woman in the US is as likely to suffer a maternal death as a woman in sanctions-hit Iran, and four times as likely as a woman in Germany.
"It is a preventable health issue," said Amnesty International's Rachel Ward. "It isn't something that we're waiting for a cure for. We’re waiting for political will."
What's worse is that US maternal mortality rates may actually be on the rise. Eugene Declercq, of Boston University's School of Public Health, produced a short film named Birth by the numbers, discussing maternal mortality in the US. In a 2013 follow-up report, he noted how mortality rates in other industrialised nations had declined - but in the US, it increased by 30 percent in the first decade of the new millennium.
